title: States accuse govt of hamping tax debate
text:
Tue, Jul 21, 2015, 11:56 AM NZST - New Zealand Markets close in 5 hrs 4 mins States accuse govt of hamping tax debate AAP – 1 hour 1 minute ago Recommend Print 
The states have gone on the offensive, accusing the federal government of stymieing debate about tax reform amid a fresh proposal to hike the GST. 
The GST will be at the centre of discussions when Prime Minister Tony Abbott and state and territory leaders meet on Wednesday. 
NSW Premier Mike Baird has proposed lifting the tax from 10 per cent to 15 per cent to help fund the future health needs of the nation, accompanied by compensation for households. 
Labor leaders, South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill and ACT Chief Minister Andrew Barr, welcomed Mr Baird's suggestion but stopped short of offering wholehearted support. 
Mr Weatherill wants to know how compensation would work and whether it could be locked in, although he doesn't want to "chop off" debate. 
"We can't enter these discussions by just ruling things out," he told ABC radio on Tuesday. 
The premier accused federal Treasurer Joe Hockey of trying to do just that. 
Mr Hockey last week declared "game over" after Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews said he wouldn't support a GST increase. 
"Every time it looks like we're heading towards a constructive discussion Joe Hockey bobs up to try and undermine the opportunity for reaching agreement," Mr Weatherill said. 
He believes Mr Hockey only wants a GST increase to create "a back door opportunity for Joe to hand out some tax cuts to his mates". 
"What we (the states) want to do is to use the revenue that's raised from this to protect an important public service, that is, the funding of public hospitals and also public education," Mr Weatherill said. 
"It can't be frittered away on other things and certainly not on tax cuts." 
Mr Barr, who is also ACT treasurer, said the commonwealth had failed to contribute constructively to the taxation debate. 
"Their budgetary position hasn't helped the states and territories and their approach to the taxation reform debate more broadly has been unhelpful," Mr Barr told ABC radio. 
The debate should be about the best mix of tax reforms to fairly and efficiently raise needed revenue. 
"Just because it's difficult doesn't mean that we shouldn't try," Mr Barr said. 
Like Victoria's premier, he's also raised the prospect of a hike to the Medicare levy. 
West Australian Premier Colin Barnett has backed a GST overhaul, to increase the rate to 12.5 per cent and extend it to online goods and fresh food, according to The West Australian. 
Meanwhile, two sets of economic modelling suggests a 15 per cent GST would hit the average Australian household hard.
